 ARGENTINA EL NINO EMERGENCY FLOOD PROJECT TECHNICAL ANNEX L. BACKGROUND AND STRATEGY A. El Nifio Impact in Argentina 1. The El Niho Phenomenon. El Nifio is the biggest cause of climate variability in the world. El Niflo is Spanish for "Christ Child", given that name because of its early December manifestation in the coastal Pacific waters of Peru and Equador, where abnormally warm sea surface temperatures (SSTs) often signal the beginning of positive SST anomalies over the eastern half of the equatorial Pacific. In parallel, there is an atmospheric phenomenon known as the Southern Oscillation, named and described by Sir Gilbert Walker, which consists of an east-west atmospheric pressure see-saw, causing changes in the Pacific trade winds, that directly affects tropical weather around the globe. Given that these two events occur in parallel, scientists refer to it as the El Nifno/Southern Oscillation phenomenon (ENSO), though for simplicity, the event is generally referred to as El Nifio. 3. Normal conditions. El Nifio is a cyclical event that occurs every three to seven years and lasts for approximately two years. Each El Nifio has its own characteristics; no one observed cycle has repeated itself to date. During normal conditions the trade winds blow toward the west across the tropical Pacific. These winds pile up warm surface water in the western Pacific, so that the sea surface is about one-half meter higher at Indonesia than at Ecuador. The sea surface temperature is also about eight degrees Celsius (C) higher in the west, with cool temperatures off the Pacific coast of South America arising because of an upwelling of cold water from deeper ocean levels. This cold water is nutrient-rich, supporting high levels of primary productivity, diverse marine ecosystems, and major fisheries. Rainfall comes from the rising air over the warmest water, while the eastern Pacific is relatively dry. Observations have shown that the cool water (generally below about 170 C) is within 50 meters of the sea surface. 4. El Niuo conditions. During an El Nifio the prevailing low-pressure system over Indonesia moves eastward, weakening the high pressure system near South America (the difference in atmospheric pressure is measured between Darwin and Tahiti). As a result the easterly trade winds relax in the central and western Pacific. The water that has accumulated in the western Pacific now has no force holding it in place. The Pacific behaves like a bath tub that is suddenly lifted at one end, that is the warm surface water that has built up in the west slopes back eastward, reversing the direction of the sea surface current. Sea levels and SST off the coast of South America rise, and the thernocline (the temperature gradient between cold and warm water) is pushed down to a much deeper level, leading to a depression of the thermocline (known as a warm phase) in the eastern Pacific Ocean waters and an elevation of the thermocline in the west (Australia). Rainfall follows the warm water eastward, causing flooding in Peru, southern Brazil,
 -2- and northern Argentina and draught in the western Pacific (Indonesia and Australia). The eastward discharge of the atmospheric heat source overlying the warmest waters result in large changes in the global atmospheric circulation, which in turn causes global climate variability. Weather anomalies occur all over the globe every year, but a distinctive few do tend to recur with most or all El Nifio events and are thus referred to as teleconnections (climate anomalies associated with El Nifno). 5. La Ninia conditions. At the end of the El Niflo cycle is an equally important occurrence: La Nifia. This event is marked by the injection of water that is colder than usual (a rise in the thermocline), causing the waters of the eastern Pacific to cool considerably. This event has the opposite impact of the El Nifo event, meaning droughts occur where floods once were and above-normal rainfall in draught areas, causing floods even in eastern Australia. 6. During the last century more than a dozen El Nifno events have affected the South American coast. Graph 1 of Appendix 1 shows the Multivariate ENSO Index, or MEI, (positive values indicate El Nifio) used by the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Agency to illustrate the strength of the six strongest (measured) El Nifnos of the century. The milder El Nifio events raise water temperatures only a degree or two along the 5,000-mile equatorial Pacific band. The stronger events, like the El Nifio of 1982-83, raise temperatures 5-10Â°C and have had a major impact not only on local weather but on climatic conditions around the globe. 7. The first three events (1957-58, 1965-66, and 1972-73) all featured an early warming in the far eastern Pacific and reached their standardized peak before the end of the first year. The more recent events (1982-83, 1986-87, and 1991-92) took longer to mature, lacking the early warming in the eastern Pacific, and typically reached their peak in the spring of their second year or even later. 8. El Nino impact in Argentina. In Latin America, particularly Argentina, El Ninio events have coincided with severe flooding in the Parana River basin (Appendix 2), a 2,600,000 km2 area that encompasses important regions of Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, and Uruguay, and Paraguay in its entirety. The 1982-83 event gave rise to the worst flooding in the Parana basin in the twentieth century, with an estimated US$1.8 billion in economic losses. Along with the flooding came incidences disease breakouts, given the damage to potable water and sanitation facilities, and the collapse of other social infrastructure services, such as electricity, roads, telephones, schools, hospitals, and housing. On a smaller scale, the 1992 flood, which coincided with the 1991-92 El Nifio, also had a tremendous impact on the basin, with economic losses at US$905 million and 3.1 million inhabitants flooded. The moderate 1966 and 1977 floods resulted in about US$750 million and US$266 million in economic losses, respectively. However, as the region develops economically', the number of people affected increases each time there is a new flood, even if the flood is of a lesser magnitude. The export growth rate of the northeast provinces in 1994 was greater than that of any other region, reflecting good cereals, cotton, petroleum, and tea expansion, particularly in Chaco and Corrientes. (Staff Appraisal Report, "Argentina: Flood Protection Project", October 29, 1996).
 -3- 9. The 1997-98 El Nino. The return of El Ninio was first detected in the eastern Pacific in May 1997. This event has reached the time of year when seasonal persistence should guarantee full-blown El Nino conditions through at least early 1998. Indicators used to monitor the event show that it has matured very quickly, appearing to have reached its standardized peak (nearly +2.9 units above normal conditions in July-August 1997) before the end of the first year. This event shows a similar pattern of development to those of 1957-58, 1965-66, and 1972-73, although has the strength of that of the 1982-83 event. Although these temperature anomalies started earlier than in 1982-83, they could, if sustained through the southem hemnisphere's summer months (December-April), give rise to rainfall on a scale experienced in 1982-83 (Map A and B of Appendix 1). 10. Based on the behavior to date and statistical correlation with trends in the past, when early maturing occurs, a quick oscillation in the cycle tends to occur, giving rise to a La Nifia event in June-July of the following year. This consensus is also shared by the scientific community and predicted in several climate models used by the National Weather Service (NWS), the Center for Ocean, Land and Atmosphere Studies (COLA), and the Bureau of Meteorology Research Center (BMRC). Such an occurrence would lead to above-normal rainfall in the northwestern provinces of Argentina. (Appendix 3 contains an analysis on the possible impact of El Nifno in Argentina over the course of the next six to nine months.) 11. The impact of the 1997-98 on Argentina. The signs of El Nifo have been present for several months in the Parana basin. In southern Brazil substantial rains have flooded the Uruguay River, which discharges directly into the Parana river delta. The Uruguay River has historically not been a source of severe flooding until this year, in which it exceeded the 100-year flood event. In fact, in the major city of Concordia (Entre Rios), that has a river flow discharge record since 1898, has suffered damages from floods as never before. El Nifio-related floods have affected a population of about 200,000 since July 1997. As of November 24, 1997 about 12,500 people had been evacuated from their homes in four different provinces (Table 1, Appendix 1), 11,600 of them living in the provinces of Corrientes and Entre Rios, which borders the Uruguay River. What is even more unusual is that when the Uruguay River floods, it does so for a short amount time because of its steeply sloped riverbed. However, the Parana River has been flowing full all year (approximately 1.5 meters above normal river height), impeding the Uruguay River from flowing into the delta. The Parana River has had an elevated flow because the Pantanal (a large wet-land region in southern Brazil and Paraguay) in Paraguay has been roughly 2.0 meters over its normal water height since April 1997. 12. As previously mentioned, there is a consensus that this year's El Nifio could quickly diverge into the cold phase around June-July 1998. Such an occurrence would bring less precipitation to the ParanA basin, while the arid and semi-arid regions of the northwest would be susceptible to an increase in rainfall. Taking into consideration the region's geomorphological characteristics and snowmelt period (1997 recorded an above-normal accumulation of 20 meters of snowpack), this would mean the occurrence of flash floods and mudslides. Although flash floods are not persistent floods, like those in the ParanA that impede long-term rehabilitation efforts, they can sweep away urban infrastructure and damage related services in a matter of minutes, causing social, economic, and environmental losses, and, even worse, the loss of human life.

As a consequence of the serious floodings of the Parana, Paraguay and Uruguay basins in 1992, the Government of Argentina (GoA) asked the Bank to finance an emergency project to rehabilitate the damaged infrastructure across all sectors. The Bank answered the request by providing US$170 million to finance the US$270 million Flood Rehabilitation Project (Loan 3521-AR) and by amending US$20 million from the Provincial Development Project (Loan 3280-AR). During the execution of the Flood Rehabilitation Project, SUCCE contracted several studies on the integrated management of the alluvial basins of the Parana, Paraguay, and Uruguay. As a result from these studies undertaken, the Flood Protection Project (Loan 4117-AR) was defined and prepared to further enhance protection of the provinces located in the littoral region. In order to achieve this greater protection, both structural and non- structural measures were incorporated into project design. 14. Current government response. The Federal Government, through assessments undertaken by the provinces, has developed a plan to mitigate current and forecast disasters through: (i) a protection and rehabilitation phase for the northwestern provinces (Salta, Jujuy, Tucuman, Santiago del Estero, Catamarca, and La Rioja) that are expected to be affected in March-June 1998; and (ii) a rehabilitation phase for the littoral provinces (Misiones, Formosa, El Chaco, Corrientes, Entre Rios, Santa Fe, and Buenos Aires) of the Parana basin already affected. The protection phase is set to be implemented in anticipation of El Niuo, and the rehabilitation phase once El Nino has occurred. Criteria to define the arrival and severity of El Nio are included in the Project Operational Manual (POM). Authorities from the Government of Argentina have requested assistance from the Bank in further defining and preparing of such a plan, along with help to meet the identified requirements for each phase. Based on the preparation done by the provinces and the Central Government of Argentina, the Bank has responded in a "fast track" mode to assist with the implementation of this strategy. 15. Mobilization of other sources. While design and preparation of the proposed loan develops, there has been an effort to respond immediately to the flooding in the littoral provinces, along the Uruguay River, and the possible consequences of El Nino in the northwestern provinces. The Government of Argentina has taken actions to identify financial resources to address the current emergency in both geographic regions. The Ministry of Interior, through the Secretaria de Asistencia Financiera a las Provincias (SAFP), analyzed all Bank-financed projects and the possibility of reallocating funds from those projects that are linked to provincial development in the mentioned regions. Further actions on connunication and coordination among governments and how to prepare for the impact of El Niio in each region were agreed on between the Federal and provincial authorities over the course of several meetings and seminars (Appendix 4) held since August of 1997. In these meetings, the SUPCEs and the provincial Department of Hydraulics were given the responsibility of communication of the El Niflo event to the public at the subnational level, while at the national level the Department of National Civil Protection would be responsible. 16. The Bank, in response to the Government's initial requests for assistance, immediately identified approximately US$118 million of uncommitted funds from existing loans that could be quickly reallocated to provide an immediate source of funding for emergency works. Although funds have been identified, certain provincial governments face such situations that they had to declare states of emergencies to place into motion mechanisms that allow for better management of disaster relief As of July 1, 1997, the GoA acknowledged the signs of the El Niiio phenomenon in the country and the severe consequences it implies. Three of the littoral provinces (as of print date) have declared a state of emergency: (i) the Province of Chaco on October 15, 1997 (Decree 2246-97); (ii) the Province of Corrientes on October 29, 1997, for a period of one year (Decree 4329-97); and (iii) the Province of Entre Rios on November 11, 1997, declaring that the state emergency began on August 31, 1997 (Decree 4060-97). More provinces are expected to declare states of emergency as the elevated river flows move south into the delta provinces. C. Lessons Learned from Previous Projects 18. The main lesson is that physical rehabilitation alone is not adequate to reduce the risk of future damage and thus sustain the benefits of the project, as well as to safeguard the people and the communities at risk. Therefore, a combination of structural and non-structural measures must be taken. Activities should be developed and coordinated, with the capacity to manage emergencies at the provincial and local levels. The successful progress made in the Flood Rehabilitation Project can be replicated by applying the following principles: (i) using investments that are simple and easy to implement; (ii) designing projects to be flexible and not over-specified, with the design being part of an ongoing process; (iii) encouraging participation of interested provinces; (iv) maintaining highly competent local executing units with the capacity to deal with emergencies; and (v) retaining the flexibility to shift funds among eligible provinces. D. Rationale for Bank Assistance 19. Given the scientific community's forecast of a potentially damaging El Nifio event, the Bank's underlying purpose in Argentina is to help keep the affected regions on an economic and
 -6- social development track through a systematic and cost-effective protection and rehabilitation program. The experience gained from the Flood Rehabilitation Project makes the Bank uniquely qualified, in the Government's view, to guide another emergency assistance program. In addition, the investments required to carry out this program are unlikely to be mobilized from the private sector. 20. The Bank's country assistance strategy (CAS), which was discussed at the Board on May 15, 1997, aims to: (a) enhance social development, including poverty alleviation and human resource development; (b) improve the performance and institutional capacity of government, particularly subnational govermnents, to deliver key social, infrastructure and environmental services; and (c) make successful structural reforms, including enhancement of governance through institution building. Although the proposed emergency assistance operation was not included in the CAS, it fully supports CAS objectives. It would advance the badly required infrastructure base in the flood-prone areas and further enhance the provinces' capacity to manage future emergencies. This ability is especially important in the flood-affected areas because of their economic importance and their connection to MERCOSUR. Minimizing social and economic disruption is critical to a long-term strategy of economic growth and poverty alleviation. The project will have its greatest impact on the poorer northwestern provinces. II. The Project A. Objective 21. The objective of the proposed project is to help the GoA's strategy to finance the development and implementation of physical and institutional actions to address the impact of the El Niuo phenomenon in the: (i) northwestern provinces of: Catamarca; Jujuy; La Rioja; Salta; Santiago del Estero; Tucuman; and the Cuyo provinces of Mendoza, San Juan and San Luis; and (ii) seven littoral provinces of Buenos Aires, El Chaco, Corrientes, Entre Rios, Formosa, Misiones, and Santa Fe through additional works above and beyond the Flood Protection Project. The specific project activities include assisting in the minimizing of loss or damage by way of protection actions and the rehabilitation of infrastructure and related services to their existing state prior to the emergency. An additional objective is to strengthen institutions in the northwestern provinces to deal with flood emergencies. B. Preparation 22. Based on the Government's request for assistance to rehabilitate the damaged infrastructure of the littoral provinces and to protect and rehabilitate (rehabilitation circa June/July 1998) infrastructure in the northwestern provinces, key members of SUCCE (Appendix 5) came to Washington from November 13-24, 1997 to undertake the identification an preparation of a possible emergency assistance loan. During SUCCE's mission to the Bank's headquarters, identification, preparation and assessment of the adequacy of the existing institutional capacity for dealing with flood emergencies and of works to be executed under the proposed loan took place. The identification of works were based on the official requests from afflicted provinces and
 -7- provinces expected to be impacted by El Nifno (Appendix 6). SUTCCE's familiarity with the state of condition of the infrastructure in the region, due to participating in numerous missions in the early months of 1997, to identify and evaluate damages incurred from recurring torrential rainfall, facilitated understanding the required needs. Only the works considered to have the highest priority were included in the emergency assistance loan and in the mobilization of financial resources from existing loans (Appendix 6). Given the numerous amounts of works identified, not all of the demand could be addressed within this emergency loan and the modification of the existing loans. Thus, in following the Government's strategy in the northwestern region, it was mentioned the identification of a subsequent operation in order to further carry out flood forecasting and prevention capabilities to manage the impact of severe flooding in the region (to be prepared at a later date). Beyond November 24, 1997, the chief executive officer and the SUCCE counsel remained in Washington to carry out the preparation of legal documents and provide additional input in the preparation of Bank documents. Negotiations took place from December 9-11, 1997. C. Description. 23. The proposed project is based on the Bank's effort to assist countries which are expected to be affected by El Niflo. The project is designed with two geographical components, one for the northwestern provinces and one for the seven participating littoral provinces of the Parana basin. A third component is included to address the incremental strengthening of SUCCE's administrative and technical capacity to coordinate the implementation of the Project, including its capacity to carry out project account audits. Given that the Loan would be made prior to the full impacts of the aftermath of the El Nifno event, the proposed operation is designed to be implemented in two distinct phases: (a) a protection phase of about 12 months for the northwestern provinces; and (b) a rehabilitation phase for both geographic regions, estimated to require up to three years. Eligibility criteria for investments under each phase will be included in the Project Operational Manual (POM). In addition, the project includes for the northwestern provinces a capacity-building (establishment of SUPCE and civil defense strengthening) sub- component to manage flood emergencies and a small scale housing sub-component. There is no provincial institutional capacity investment sub-component for the littoral provinces because of the current institutional mechanism placed into existence from the Flood Rehabilitation and Flood Protection Projects. Detail project description is outlined in Appendix 7. 24. Protection works (US$10.0 million) for northwest region. This phase will finance strengthening and maintenance measures in the northwestern provinces of key river defense components, such as levees, embankment protection, channel bed cleaning and debris removal actions, along with the construction of primary drainage canals. The works can be viewed in terms of controlling waters originating from outside the urban zone while controlling and channeling water originating within the protected urban zone to outside. Transport infrastructure will be addressed through strengthening of bridges and adjacent road embankments from the scouring affects of bottlenecked waters. The inclusion of this phase is to take a pro-active approach to placing investments in high risk locations prior to the expected heavy rainfall, so as to lessen the economic and social disruption of the La Nifia event.

Rehabilitation works will need to be undertaken immediately in the littoral provinces, in particular those provinces located along the Uruguay River and in rural provincial interior locations. While the rehabilitation works to be done in the northwestern provinces can not be fully ascertained until approximately June 1998. These works may vary in magnitude, depending on the geographical impact of El Nifno and whether the protection works were executed in locations in which the most amount of damaged was avoided. Nevertheless, the rehabilitation of infrastructure includes: (i) health and education facilities; (ii) transport infrastructure, specifically bridges; (iii) river defenses, river training construction; (iv) channel clean-up; (v) water supply and sewerage (northwest only); and (vi) drainage networks. Though the rehabilitation works to be financed for the northwestern provinces will not be known with certainty until after June 1998, all rehabilitation works for financing under the Bank project must be identified and presented to the Bank no later than 24 months after the effectiveness date of the project (uncommitted funds after 24 months will be canceled). The POM will include indicators which establish the criteria for when a major weather event has occurred and thus triggering the eligibility for Bank financing of the necessary rehabilitation works. The rehabilitation phase of the project will be addressed in ongoing basis during scheduled yearly Bank full supervision missions. 26. Technical Assistance (US$9.9 million). Technical assistance (TA) for the proposed project will be essentially for the northwestern provinces, except for: (i) the engineering and supervision of works to be carried out in the littoral component (US$666,000); and (ii) the strengthening of SUCCE's administrative and technical capacity (US$450,000), including project accounts auditing (US$400,000), which will both be cost shared by all participating provinces. Nhile TA for the littoral provinces in terms of regional studies, flood warning systems, civil defense capacity and others were defined in the Flood Protection Project and thus will be funded through that loan. 27. The TA sub-component for the northwest encompasses many of the items covered for the littoral provinces under the ongoing project, which are: (i) the establishment of a SUPCE in each participating province and its institutional strengthening (US$3.6 million); (ii) civil defense strengthening capacity (US$1.8 million) through training and development of a provincial emergency plan, acquisition of communication equipment and flood forecasting technology (all but acquisition of equipment to be undertaken by SUCCE); (iii) housing technical assistance (US$ 186,000); (iv) a regional environmental study (US$2.1 million) to be integrated with the regional flood-risk mapping, undertaken by SUCCE (environmental assessment of the whole region and recommended necessary measures to reduce the impact of flood protection actions, especially in those zones where periodic floodings affect sensitive ecosystems, TOR guidelines- Appendix 8); and (v) basic and detailed engineering designs and engineering supervision during construction (US$656,000). 28. The TA assistance is fundamental to the establishment of a long-term strategy in flood management coordination. The regional flood-risk study will delineate within basins of the northwest the basic notion of where defense investments should be located and where new development should occur. In order to carry out the institutional strengthening through the creation of a SUPCE and the strengthening of civil defense capacity, an estimated 1,500 man-
 -9- months will be required for three years, or roughly the contracting of six to seven individuals per year for each province in the northwestern component. 29. Housing (US$1.9 million). This sub-component has been assigned to serve as a mechanism for institutional capacity building to the newly created SUPCEs of the northwestern provinces. Given that the housing process is being introduced, each new SUPCE will be designated only 50 housing units and will be implemented with the guidance of SUCCE, which successfully supervised the execution of more than 5,800 housing units under the Flood Rehabilitation Project. 30. The basic is that a voluntary self-construction housing system will be provided for low- income families located in areas highly vulnerable to floods and/or to those families whom have had their dwelling severely damaged or destroyed by the flooding in the northwestern provinces. Their new houses would be constructed in higher areas close to their present sites or in their present sites with elevated foundations, if possible, to minimize dislocation, The housing units would be designed based on the same criteria established in the Flood Protection Project. The housing units would be 43 in2, with two bedrooms, a multi-use room, a shaded area and water and drainage installations for the kitchen and bathroom. The cost for each unit would be about US$6,200. D. Cost 31. The total cost of the prevention and rehabilitation phases for the proposed project is estimated to be US$60.0 million, of which a vast majority would be local expenditures. Costs are expressed in November 1997 prices and are based on experience with the previous two projects (Loan 3521-AR and 4117-AR) and other similar projects in the area. Of the US$60.0 million, US$35.0 would be initially allocated to the northwestern provinces and US$25.0 to the littoral provinces. Of the US$35.0 million for the northwestern provinces, the flood prevention phase is estimated to be US$15.0 million and the rehabilitation is estimated to be US$20.0 million. The initial US$25.0 million allocation for the littoral provinces is designated towards rehabilitation. Physical and price contingencies calculations came out to be about 10.9 percent of the total cost of goods and works, collectively, for the project. Contingencies were dependent upon the geographical region in which the goods were bought and the location of where the works were executed. A summary of the project costs is presented in the Table 1 of Appendix 9. All costs are expressed in US dollars because of the parity between the dollar and the peso, as established in the Borrower's Convertibility Law (No. 23928 of April 1991). E. Financing 32. IMPACTO DEL FENOMENO ENOS EN LA REPUBLICA ARGENTINA El fen6meno ENOS, tanto en su fase calida como fria, produce un impacto importante en la hidroclimatologia de varias regiones en la Republica Argentina. CUENCAS DEL PARAN4, PARAGUAY Y URUGUAY La cuenca de los rios Parana, Paraguay y Uruguay son grandemente afectadas por los episodios calidos y frios del fen6meno ENOS. En los uiltimos afios crecidas en estos rios han causado dafios por arriba de $1000 millones de d6lares en cada oportunidad. Existen varios estudios en los cuales se puede evaluar el impacto en la hidrometeorologia de la zona sur del Brasil, Paraguay y nordeste Argentino. Uno de ellos es el estudio de Anderson y otros (1994) en el cual se determina que, bajo un criterio regional, los afios con episodios calidos del fen6meno ENOS. El criterio regional es que se produce, al menos en una de las 10 estaciones fluviom6tricas de estas cuencas, un evento con periodo de recurrencia superior a los 10 afios. Para ilustrar el impacto en los caudales de los rios de esta cuenca se realiz6 un estudio de las probabilidades de excedencia de los caudales estacionales (tres meses: Diciembre-Febrero, Marzo-Mayo, Junio-Agosto y Septiembre-Noviembre) del rio Parana en Corrientes, despues de la confluencia con el rio Paraguay.  -48- Appendix 4 Course of Actions Taken by Central and Local Governments In June of 1997, selected members of SUCCE and a Bank representative were lead by Dr. Juan Valdes to key sites of flood defense structures and to US Army Corps of Engineers district and division offices throughout the Mississippi Valley Basin and in Washington, DC The tour encompassed exposure to both structural and non-structural measures taken by different US Government agencies in regards to flood protection efforts. In the littoral provinces several events have transpired. In late August of 1997, the First Seminar on Hydro-meterology in the Plata Basin (Primer Encuentro de Hidrometereologia de la Cuenca Plata) took place in the province of Chaco, where delegates (involved in, among others, the SUPCEs and civil defense) from the all of the littoral provinces and those from the central level (SUCCE, National Civil Defense, Secretary of Social Development of the President of the Nation, Ministry of the Environment and others) were present. During the seminar, the El Nifio phenomenon was analyzed in terms of its forecast and impacts for the remainder of 1997 and the beginning months of 1998, and what preventive actions should be addressed in terms of structural and non-structural measures. On October 2, 1997, SUCCE held a meeting with the littoral provinces to analyze the functioning of the hydraulic alert system (flood forecasting) which was implemented under the Flood Rehabilitation Project. In addition, actions were agreed to for the short-term adjustment and actualization of the communication system with the provinces, including the acquisition of necessary supplemental goods. In the long-term, actions were agreed to modernize the system on a regional scale. This meeting was followed up with a second meeting on October 23, 1997, where the necessities for the system were finalized and a commission, consisting of representatives from the provinces, SUCCE and the Institute for water and the Environment, was created November 3, 1997, marked the meeting with in the Secretary of Public Works of the Ministry of Economics and Works and Public Services of the Nation with the participation of the distinctive national entities (including SUCCE) where they discussed the problems that the phenomenon presents and the already occurring floodings in the country.  -55- Appendix 8 Guidelines for Terms of Reference for Consultants to Undertake a Regional Flood- risk Zoning of the Northwestern Provinces LINEAMIENTOS GENERALES PARA TERMINOS DE REFERENCIA El prop6sito de esta secci6n es la definici6n de algunos criterios para la determinaci6n de los terminos de referencia de estudios para la determinacion de mapas de zonas de riesgo para las provincias del noroeste de Argentina. Estos mapas de zonas de riesgo permitiran una mejor prestaci6n de los prestamos de emergencia. Es importante recalcar que, sin la definici6n de las zonas de riesgo, es imposible estimar las caracteristicas y las frecuencias de eventos extremos. La experiencia de las inundaciones del Medio Oeste en los EEUU en el afio 1993 indican la dificultad de evaluar el periodo de retorno de una inundaci6n en una regi6n. Por ejemplo la recurrencia de la crecida del 1993 fue de 50 afios en St. Paul (Minnesota), menos de 100 afnos en Lincoln (Nebraska) a mas de 100 affos en St. Louis (Missouri). De mas de 500 estaciones hidrometricas del US Geological Survey en la zona del alto Mississippi, 45 estaciones excedieron el nivel de recurrencia de 100 aflos pero al menos 450 no lo hicieron (Interagency Floodplain Management Review Committee, 1994). Solo sectores del Mississippi Superior y del Missouri alcanzaron un periodo de recurrencia de 500 afios. La deterniinaci6n de las zonas de riesgo debe ser mas completa que la determinaci6n de la linea de la creciente de 100-afnos, mas apropiadamente Ilamada la creciente con una probabilidad de ocurrencia de 1% en cada afno ("one-percent standard", Lord, 1994). Generalmente, al menos en los EEUU, los usuarios localizados en la planicie de inundaci6n debajo de la linea del 1% tienden a creer, err6neamente, que el riesgo es el mnismo en cualquier sitio de la planicie. Un ejemplo de la determinaci6n de mapas de zonas de riesgo de inundaci6n en zonas semi-aridas, como las del noroeste Argentino, puede verse en Marco (1994). En ese estudio las zonas de riesgo fueron clasificadas en las siguientes categorias: zonas de inundaci6n masiva; conos aluviales, desaparici6n de cauces efimeros; cuencas cerradas y zonas muy concentradas de escasa area pero de alta probabilidad de inundaci6n ('black spots"). En este estudio se demostr6 que la mayor parte del problema es urbano y se debi6 al crecimiento desordenado cuyas consecuencias fueron remediadas con medidas estructurales. En el estudio se determin6 que el 80% de las medidas estructurales podrian haberse evitado si se hubiera llevado a cabo una zonificaci6n adecuada de la planicie de inundaci6n. INCERTIDUMBRES EN LA DETERMINA CIONDE LAS ZONAS DE RIESGO En la determinaci6n de las zonas de riesgo deben tenerse en cuenta las incertidumbres en la determinaci6n de la magnitud de las crecientes y su extensi6n areal. Esto no es habitualmente mostrado en los planos de riesgo de inundaciones. Por ejemplo estimaciones de la creciente con un periodo de retorno de 100 aflos puede tener una variaci6n de un 5% a un 45% (Burkham, 1978). Esta incertidumbre aumenta notablemente para la definici6n de crecientes con un mayor periodo de recurrencia. Una incertidumbre adicional es la transformaci6n de una creciente en su equivalente nivel. Esto se hace habitualmente por intermedio de una curva de altura-caudal o por medio de un modelo
 -56- hidraulico. En el estudio del Interagency Floodplain Management Review Committee (1994) se citan errores del orden de 0.2 a 2 pies. Adicionalmente existe la imperfecci6n de los mapas topograficos. En el estudio mencionado se estima que la definici6n del nivel de la linea de la creciente de 100 afios puede tener una variaci6n promedio del 23% con respecto al valor estimado. SELECCIONDE UNNI VEL DE FRECUENCIA PARA PRtSTAMOS DE EMERGENCIA Dada la alta variabilidad espacial del periodo de retomo de un fen6meno de inundaciones es dificil la selecci6n de un valor regional de frecuencia y debe seleccionarse un valor puntual para la determinaci6n de la adjudicacion de un prestamo de emergencia. El caudal de disefio de una obra hidraulica para control o atenuaci6n de crecidas depende de las caracteristicas de la obra. Existen tres criterios para la selecci6n de este nivel (Chow y otros, 1988): * Criterio empirico: se adjudica un determinado periodo de recurrencia basado totalmente en la probabilidad de excedencia. Por ejemplo generalmente se diseflan puentes en caminos secundarios con un periodo de recurrencia entre 10-50 afios y en carreteras principales con un periodo de retorno entre 50 y 100 afios. • Criterio de riesgo: es una extension del criterio empirico donde la probabilidad de excedencia durante la vida uitil del proyecto es tenida en cuenta, es decir R = (1 - I/T)r donde T es el periodo de retorno y n es el numero de aflos en la vida util del proyecto. A este valor se lo modifica con un factor de seguridad. * Analisis hidro-econ6mico: en este estudio se determina el periodo 6ptimo de disefio en base al caracter probabilistico de las crecidas y al impacto econ6mico de las mismas sobre el rango factible de eventos hidrologicos. Dada la escasa informaci6n que se estima esta disponible se recomienda que en esta fase del proyecto se adopten criterios basados totalmente en la frecuencia. Se recomienda, por lo tanto, una creciente de disefno de 50 afios en el sitio como el umbral a partir del cual se aprobara el uso de los fondos de emergencia. Este periodo de recurrencia es lo suficientemente alto para justificar reparaciones mayores al sistema de drenaje, comunicaciones, etc de la regi6n pero al mismo tiempo con una frecuencia de ocurrencia alta (riesgo de 55% en un periodo de 30 afios). La mayoria de las obras principales de infraestructura se disefian con un periodo igual o mayor a 50 afios.  -60- Appendix 10 Project Operational Manual (POM) To facilitate project implementation, a Project Operational Manual based on the revised POM from the Flood Protection Project will be used. Lessons learned during the implementation of the two ongoing flood projects would be incorporated into the new POM. Among other aspects, the POM includes: (i) eligibility for protection works and indicators that trigger eligibility for rehabilitation; (ii) procurement procedures; (iii) housing grant procedures; (iv) provincial fund allocation and reallocation guidelines; (v) disbursement procedures; (vi) SUCCE structure and responsibilities; (vii) structure and responsibilities of each SUPCE; and (viii) project monitoring and auditing. Eligibility indicators: The POM includes a list of types of infrastructure that will be eligible for Bank financing for the protection phase in the northwestern component of the project. Also, guidelines will be established on where the best location for such protection investments should be made. The POM will also include a set of criteria that must be met that signal that a significant weather event has taken place and that the resulting damaged occurred was from the excessive rainfall endured in the region and that rehabilitation may commence. Procurement procedures: The POM will include a detailed set of instructions to the implementation agencies (SUPCEs) to apply adequately the procurement procedures based on the Bank Guidelines for procurement of goods and works as well as for selection of consultants. The POM includes also the agreed procedures for NCB, shopping and direct contracting. The POM will also include arrangements for SUCCE supervision of procurement actions and review of bidding documents. The agreed standard bidding documents for all procurement of goods and works are to be annexed in the POM. Housing grant procedures: The POM will describe in detail the agreed criteria and procedures for eligibility for the housing grant, as well as procedures to be followed by the SUPCEs to distribute and control the vouchers and to help the beneficiaries to construct their houses. These are the same guidelines and criteria established in the Flood Protection Project. Fund allocation: The POM will include, based on identified investments during project preparation, the amount of funds initially allocated to each province. The POM will also establish the guidelines and timetables for fund reallocation. Disbursement procedures: The POM will include details in the procedures to be followed by the SUPCEs to disburse from special accounts. They are based on the Bank disbursement procedures and based on experience gained during the implementation of the previous projects. The POM will also include the arrangements for SUCCE control and supervision of disbursement activities by the SUPCEs. SUCCE structure and responsibilities: The POM will define SUCCE as a group of consultants funded by the loan proceeds of the Flood Protection Project and by the El Nifio Emergency Flood Project for the supplementary staff required to administer and implement the additional work load brought on by the northwestern component. SUCCE will continue to report to the UEC of the SAFP. SUCCE will be headed by an executive chief and will be composed of professionals in each sector of project implementation, having as a minimum: (i) project
 -61- supervisor, reporting directly to the SAFP and to the Bank; (ii) an accounting expert; (iii) a disbursement expert; (iv) a procurement expert; (v) an environmental expert; (vi) a flood defense expert; (vii) a civil engineering expert; (viii) a hydrologist; (ix) a housing expert; (x) an expert for shelters and civil defense actions; (xi) a drainage expert; (xii) a counsel; (xiii) an advisor for sub- project evaluations; and (xiv) support for administrative, computational, accounting, technical and disbursement activities. All new and existing professionals in SUCCE will be hired having terms of references (TOR) and the selection process shall be presented to the Bank. The POM will define as SUCCE's responsibility to oversee, supervise and control the actions of all SUPCEs, particularly in respect to identification of works to be selected for investment, sub-project design, procurement actions, implementation, supervision, disbursement, accounting and auditing. Structure and responsibility of each SUPCE: Each participating province will assign project implementation responsibility to a local SUCCE, as done in the ongoing Flood Protection Project. The SUPCE will consist of a chief executive reporting to a provincial minister or directly to the governor (in some provinces), and will have experts in a similar structure to that of SUCCE. Proceeds from the loan will finance the SUPCE staff for the six provinces identified in the northwestern component for three years. The POM establishes the arrangements for the adequate control and relationship between SUCCE and the SUPCEs. Project monitoring and auditing: The POM will establish the accounting requirements to be followed by each SUPCE and by SUCCE. The monitoring system, especially the quarterly reports to be sent to the Bank, would follow the same standard and content as those used in the two other flood projects and would follow the project monitoring and performance indicators agreed to in the POM. External independent auditors will be hired by SUCCE to audit annually all project accounts, disbursement, procurement actions and SOEs and the use of the special account. The TOR for the auditing services will be included in an annex to the POM. Guidance to contractors on environmental aspects: The POM will include an annex, as in the Flood Protection Project POM, giving guidance to contractors on procedures to be followed during the execution of works to minimize environmental effects.

 -64- Appendix 13 Financial Management System SUCCE, as defined by projects financed by the Bank, will maintain a financial management system (FMS), as in the past and as defined in the POM. The FMS will encompass accounting, financial reporting, and auditing systems, adequate to ensure that SUCCE can provide to the Bank accurate and timely information regarding project resources and expenditures. Accounting: The information submitted to the Bank by SUCCE will adhere to accounting standards acceptable to the Bank. Since SUCCE has been implementing Bank projects for over five years, it already has an established accounting and internal control system that conforms with such accounting standards that (i) reliably record and report all assets and liabilities and financial transactions involving the use of Bank funds; and (ii) provide sufficient financial information for managing and monitoring project activities. Financial Reporting: SUCCE, as governed by the legal agreements and POM, will be required to submit to the Bank within six months after the end of each fiscal year (including the fiscal year of the final disbursement) an audited financial statement of the project. The Bank will also require that SUCCE have audited financial statements of any sub-borrower's implementing agency (SUPCEs), since its financial viability is essential to project success and because one of the project objectives are to improve institutional capability. In addition, SUCCE may need to submit interim an audited statements used for project managing and monitoring purposes. Auditing: SUCCE will have itself and the provincial implementing agencies financial statements (including the Special Account and statement of expenditures) audited each year in accordance with standards acceptable to the Bank as defined by the POM. The audit of such financial statements will include: (i) an assessment of the adequacy of accounting and internal control systems to monitor expenditures and other financial transactions and ensure safe custody of project financed assets; (ii) a determination as to whether the Borrower and project implementing entities have maintained adequate documentation on all relevant transactions; (iii) verification that expenditures submitted to the Bank are eligible for financing, and identification of any ineligible expenditures; and (iv) the summary of Special Account (SA) activities and a summary of statement of expenditure (SOE) disbursements. The SA and SOEs are to be addresses separately by the auditor's opinion. SUCCE will ensure that an independent auditor, acceptable to the Bank, is contracted in sufficient time to carry out the required responsibilities, including a review of the FMS at the beginning of project implementation. Quality of Staff: To be able to monitor the accounts and prepare the required financial statements for the proposed project, SUCCE and the other project implementing entities will have available an adequate number and mix of skilled and experienced staff who understand the relevant accounting concepts and government regulations, as mandated in the POM (Appendix 6) as part of the SUCCE staff requirement. The staff that uphold the required internal control system will maintain that financial records are reliable and complete and adhere to management policies and proper recording and safeguarding of assets and resources. Failure to Submit Acceptable Audited Financial Statements: If: (i) failure to submit required audited financial statements by the due date; (ii) the auditor's opinion indicates
 -65- deficiencies in the accounting and internal controls (including ineligible expenditures) or in the reliability of the financial statements; or (iii) the Bank considers the scope or quality of the audit to be unacceptable, the Bank may take the following actions until acceptable audited financial statements are received or a remedial action plan is agreed: (i) discontinues use of the SOE procedure; (ii) replenishment of SA; (iii) suspension on all loan disbursements. These actions would be taken by the Bank until adequate actions have been carried out by the Botrower.

doc.repnme: Argentina - El Nino Emergency Flood Project
doc.abstracts: The objective of the El Nino Emergency Flood Project is to offset the damaging impact of El Nino in: i) six northwestern provinces and three Cuyo provinces; and ii) seven littoral provinces through additional works above and beyond the Flood Protection Project. The project has been designed with two geographical components: one for the six northwestern provinces and the three Cuyo provinces, and another for the seven participating littoral provinces. A third component is designed to strengthen the administrative and technical capacity to coordinate the implementation of the project. The operation will be implemented in two phases: 1) a protection phase of 12 months for the northwestern provinces, which includes acquiring of goods and execution of works for emergency river flood control; and b) a rehabilitation phase for both geographic regions, which includes transport infrastructure, drainage systems, education and health facilities. In addition, there is a capacity-building subcomponent for the northwestern provinces to manage flood emergencies and a small scale housing subcomponent for housing reconstruction.
